citation.article-title: Reclassification of Paenibacillus (formerly Bacillus) pulvifaciens (Nakamura 1984) Ash et al. 1994, a later subjective synonym of Paenibacillus (formerly Bacillus) larvae (White 1906) Ash et al. 1994, as a subspecies of P. larvae, with emended descriptions of P. larvae as P. larvae subsp. larvae and P. larvae subsp. pulvifaciens.

p.s: Description of Paenibacillus larvae subsp. pulvifaciens subsp. nov.
Paenibacillus larvae subsp. pulvifaciens (pul.vi.fa.ciens. L. n. pulvis, powder, dust; L. pres. part. faciens, making; M.L. adj. pulvifaciens, making powder or dust)
The morphological, chemotaxonomic, and general characters of P. larvae subsp. pulvifaciens are the same as those given above for the species.
Causes powdery scale of honeybee (A. mellifera) larvae.
Optimum growth temperature, 28 to 30°C; grows also at 20°C.
Will grow in nutrient broth on repeated subculture.

Grows on routine media such as nutrient agar, as well as on Columbia blood agar, producing unpigmented or yellow-orange-pigmented, smooth, glossy, regular, butyrous to sticky colonies 1 to 3 mm in diameter in 2 to 4 days at 30 or 37°C.
Catalase negative or weak, delayed positive.
Arginine dihydrolase is produced; nitrate is reduced to nitrite; acid is produced from mannitol but not from salicin.
The average G+C content is 42.0 to 43.3 mol% (renaturation method) or 44 mol% (buoyant-density method).
The type strain is NRRL B-3685 (LMG 6911, LMG 15974, ATCC 13537, and NCIMB 11201).
The 16s rDNA sequence of the strain NCDO 1141 is deposited in the EMBL Data Library with assigned accession no. X60636 (1).
